comment._content: Looks like a Nash Ambassador. Quirky cool car with a quirky cool paintjob for a quirky cool guy.

comment.author: 13411027@N00
comment._content: Definitely correct, it's a big Nash.

comment.author: 41553586@N02
comment._content: As soon as I saw this picture, I knew I had seen him before in my old magazine collection. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/goggomobil/9888231064/] Caption reads: HIGH-RIDING MURAL. Work of the itinerant signpainter Paul Hubbard, the fanciful art adorns his car and advertises his skills. The 66-year-old "knight of the highway" winters in Ybor City, Fla., travels the rest of the year. From: Popular Science, May 1959, page 133. If you Google 'Paul Hubbard painter', you'll see that he was well-known as 'Paul Hubbard, Hobo painter'. Example: coolopolis.blogspot.com/2013/03/paul-hubbard-media-friend... The Ambassador was a shrewd choice for exhibiting a mural; a slab-sided, rolling canvas with fairly good fuel economy.

comment.author: 31846825@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/goggomobil] Excellent information! Thanks for sharing - we've updated our catalog record.
comment.authorname: State Library and Archives of Florida

comment.author: 41553586@N02
comment._content: You're welcome. Whatever pitfalls the internet may have, its most brilliant virtue easily outweighs them all: sharing, storing and networking information. I have made a penny's worth to you. Thank you for sharing much, much more.

comment.author: 13411027@N00
comment._content:
That is SO TRUE,@glassy.    I am always finding myself telling seniors that all the theft, spam emails and porn popups are mostly engendered by one's own friends' 'fwds'  or more commonly one's own surfing endeavors.   So you can avoid all three problems by one's own behavior.  

I tell them that the reach-out ability to current and historic data is priceless, free, easy, and should at least be tried.  The information, however imperfect, has saved me years of poring over library books and old magazines.
